awd_titl_txt: Virus-vector interactions mediating the whitefly transmission of foregut-borne viruses
awd_abstract_narration:
The epidemiological spread of many insect transmitted plant viruses involves molecular interactions between the virus and a population of cells in the insect host (vector). For successful interactions and virus transmission to occur, specific virus encoded proteins are critical determinants. Virus retention sites are also essential factors and their specific locations within the insect vary among different insect-plant virus systems. The overall HYPOTHESIS to be evaluated is that transmission of foregut-borne viruses, such as the whitefly transmitted viruses in the genus Crinivirus, is mediated by specific virus capsid component(s) and specific retention sites within the foregut of the insects.   
 	A novel immunofluorescent localization assay as well as biochemical and molecular approaches will be used to address the following SPECIFIC AIMS: 1) determine if a capsid component, the minor coat protein (CPm), of the crinivirus Lettuce infectious yellows virus (LIYV) can block the specific retention and transmission of LIYV, 2) determine the specific vector retention sites of the crinivirus Lettuce chlorosis virus (LCV), 3) determine if LIYV and LCV co-localize to similar sites in their common whitefly vector, 4) identify, through the use of engineered mutants, the molecular determinants of crinivirus retention and transmission, 5) determine the atomic structure of the LIYV CPm to precisely map the amino acid determinants involved in mediating virus retention and transmission. 
Results emanating from this project will provide insights into mechanisms underlying the whitefly transmission of criniviruses, and contribute to a broader understanding of virus-vector interactions. This will facilitate the design of blocking agents aimed at controlling the spread of viruses in the future.
	BROADER IMPACTS: The training opportunities made available through this project will enable trainees of different cultural and socio-economic backgrounds to benefit from the cross-disciplinary and technological/scientific expertise provided by the participating laboratories, as well as from NSF-affiliated programs, such as the CAMP Project, established at and supported by UC Riverside.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

por.por_cntn:
Many viruses that cause destructive impacts on plant and animal life are transmitted from host to host by insect vectors.  While the individual roles that viruses and vectors play in disease and disease transmission are well recognized, mechanisms underlying virus-vector interactions mediating the transmission are poorly understood.  This project was developed to investigate transmission mechanisms mediated by the interactions between two plant viruses?lettuce infectious yellows virus (LIYV) and lettuce chlorosis virus (LCV)?in the genus Crinivirus and their whitefly (Bemisia tabaci) vectors.  Our previous studies have demonstrated that transmission of LIYV is determined by a minor virion capsid protein (CPm) that mediates the binding of virions to retention sites within the foregut of its specific vector B. tabaci biotype A.  In this project, elucidation of the CPm-mediated transmission mechanism was guided by the following objectives: 1) to determine if E. coli expressed recombinant (r) LIYV CPm could disrupt the retention and transmission of LIYV, 2) to determine the whitefly (B. tabaci biotypes A and B) vector retention sites of LCV, 3) to determine if LIYV and LCV co-localize to similar retention sites in their common vector (biotype A), 4) to generate engineered CPm mutants of LIYV and LCV, and identify the molecular determinants of virion retention and transmission, and 5) to obtain a high resolution atomic structure of LIYV CPm.  In Objective 1, our results demonstrated that vectors failed to transmit LIYV after concurrently acquiring LIYV and rCPm, and this correlated with a significant reduction in the number of vectors that retained virions in their foreguts.  Studies in Objective 2 demonstrated for the first time an association between the foregut-retention and transmission of a crinivirus (LCV) that is transmitted by two B. tabaci biotypes.  In Objective 3, we have obtained anti-LCV and anti-LIYV antibodies labeled with fluorophores that would allow us to differentiate both viruses when they bind to the foregut of the biotype A vector. Studies in Objective 4 demonstrated that a biologically active and transmissible LIYV mutant engineered with a chimeric (LIYV-LCV) CPm exhibited a novel antibody recognition pattern where the virions were distinctly labeled by antibodies directed against the LCV CPm but not the LIYV CPm.  This phenomenon was observed in vitro (by immunogold labeling TEM) and in the foreguts of biotype A vectors.  Bioinformatics and protein prediction analyses revealed a modest but interesting similarity between a region in the N-terminus of LCV CPm (embedded in the chimeric LIYV-LCV CPm) and a laminin α chain.  In Objective 5, we have made progress in a helical reconstruction of LIYV and we can even see what appears to be RNA winding up through the helical assembly.  We are currently at a modest 6? resolution and are working to refine the helical parameters and raw images.  The amino acid sequence is markedly different than all other filamentous viruses and we must get as close to 3? to trace the chain with confidence.  This work continues and we hope to have an atomic structure in the near future.

The results from our project have given us unparalleled insights into the encapsidation, foregut-retention, and whitefly transmission of criniviruses.  Together with the tools that we have developed here, they will allow us to test new hypotheses to further dissect the CPm-vector interactions-mediated transmission mechanisms of criniviruses.  Findings from our studies were presented in seven peer-reviewed papers and three refereed review articles.  The importance of our work was disseminated at twelve invited talks, as well as through six oral and two poster presentations.     

This project had been used to train several graduate students and numerous undergraduate and high school students.  In the Ng lab, two undergraduate interns who participated under the MSRIP and REU programs were co-authors in one of the papers produced from this project.  In the Smith lab, there have been more than 10 publications that has included these undergraduate and high school students. In nearly all cases, it has helped lead them towards careers in science. The PI has also incorporated some of his research efforts and outcomes into a discussion topic on 'How animal and plant viruses move?' in a lower division, non-science major course offered every fall quarter to over a hundred undergraduates, many of whom are URM students. 

 


Last Modified: 01/05/2022
Modified by: James Ng

por.por_txt_cntn:
Many viruses that cause destructive impacts on plant and animal life are transmitted from host to host by insect vectors.  While the individual roles that viruses and vectors play in disease and disease transmission are well recognized, mechanisms underlying virus-vector interactions mediating the transmission are poorly understood.  This project was developed to investigate transmission mechanisms mediated by the interactions between two plant viruses?lettuce infectious yellows virus (LIYV) and lettuce chlorosis virus (LCV)?in the genus Crinivirus and their whitefly (Bemisia tabaci) vectors.  Our previous studies have demonstrated that transmission of LIYV is determined by a minor virion capsid protein (CPm) that mediates the binding of virions to retention sites within the foregut of its specific vector B. tabaci biotype A.  In this project, elucidation of the CPm-mediated transmission mechanism was guided by the following objectives: 1) to determine if E. coli expressed recombinant (r) LIYV CPm could disrupt the retention and transmission of LIYV, 2) to determine the whitefly (B. tabaci biotypes A and B) vector retention sites of LCV, 3) to determine if LIYV and LCV co-localize to similar retention sites in their common vector (biotype A), 4) to generate engineered CPm mutants of LIYV and LCV, and identify the molecular determinants of virion retention and transmission, and 5) to obtain a high resolution atomic structure of LIYV CPm.  In Objective 1, our results demonstrated that vectors failed to transmit LIYV after concurrently acquiring LIYV and rCPm, and this correlated with a significant reduction in the number of vectors that retained virions in their foreguts.  Studies in Objective 2 demonstrated for the first time an association between the foregut-retention and transmission of a crinivirus (LCV) that is transmitted by two B. tabaci biotypes.  In Objective 3, we have obtained anti-LCV and anti-LIYV antibodies labeled with fluorophores that would allow us to differentiate both viruses when they bind to the foregut of the biotype A vector. Studies in Objective 4 demonstrated that a biologically active and transmissible LIYV mutant engineered with a chimeric (LIYV-LCV) CPm exhibited a novel antibody recognition pattern where the virions were distinctly labeled by antibodies directed against the LCV CPm but not the LIYV CPm.  This phenomenon was observed in vitro (by immunogold labeling TEM) and in the foreguts of biotype A vectors.  Bioinformatics and protein prediction analyses revealed a modest but interesting similarity between a region in the N-terminus of LCV CPm (embedded in the chimeric LIYV-LCV CPm) and a laminin α chain.  In Objective 5, we have made progress in a helical reconstruction of LIYV and we can even see what appears to be RNA winding up through the helical assembly.  We are currently at a modest 6? resolution and are working to refine the helical parameters and raw images.  The amino acid sequence is markedly different than all other filamentous viruses and we must get as close to 3? to trace the chain with confidence.  This work continues and we hope to have an atomic structure in the near future.

The results from our project have given us unparalleled insights into the encapsidation, foregut-retention, and whitefly transmission of criniviruses.  Together with the tools that we have developed here, they will allow us to test new hypotheses to further dissect the CPm-vector interactions-mediated transmission mechanisms of criniviruses.  Findings from our studies were presented in seven peer-reviewed papers and three refereed review articles.  The importance of our work was disseminated at twelve invited talks, as well as through six oral and two poster presentations.     

This project had been used to train several graduate students and numerous undergraduate and high school students.  In the Ng lab, two undergraduate interns who participated under the MSRIP and REU programs were co-authors in one of the papers produced from this project.  In the Smith lab, there have been more than 10 publications that has included these undergraduate and high school students. In nearly all cases, it has helped lead them towards careers in science. The PI has also incorporated some of his research efforts and outcomes into a discussion topic on 'How animal and plant viruses move?' in a lower division, non-science major course offered every fall quarter to over a hundred undergraduates, many of whom are URM students.
